sen.j: 寛平の治（かんぴょうのち）は、平安時代中期（9世紀後期）の宇多天皇の治世を理想視した呼称。
sen.e: Kanpyo no chi is a name of the rule by Emperor Uda in the mid-Heian Period (late 9th century) regarded as an ideal.
Kanpyo no chi is the name of the rule by Emperor Uda in the mid-Heian Period (late 9th century) which was largely regarded as ideal.

sen.j: 寛平は宇多天皇の治世の元号である。
sen.e: Kanpyo is an name of the era ruled by Emperor Uda.

sen.j: 宇多天皇は、891年（寛平3年）の関白藤原基経の死後摂関を置かず、源能有を事実上の首班として藤原時平と菅原道真、平季長等の近臣を重用し各種政治改革を行った。
sen.e: Emperor Uda did not appoint Sekkan (regents and advisers) after the death of Kanpaku FUJIWARA no Mototsune in 891, and carried out various political reforms using MINAMOTO no Yoshiari as a virtual leader and promoting trusted vassals such as FUJIWARA no Tokihira, SUGAWARA no Michizane, and TAIRA no Suenaga.

sen.j: 近年の研究では、従来から言われていた894年（寛平6年）の遣唐使廃止や896年（寛平8年）の造籍、私営田抑制、滝口の武士の設置等に加え、国司に一国内の租税納入を請け負わせる国司請負や、位田等からの俸給給付等を民部省を通さずに各国で行う等、国司の権限を強化する改革を次々と行ったとされている。

sen.j: また、天皇親政が行われた治世と評価されたが、摂関不設置は阿衡事件に懲りた宇多天皇が皇族を母とする藤原氏腹でない天皇であったことと、藤原氏藤氏長者時平がまだ若かったことが原因とされている。
sen.e: This era was highly evaluated due to the direct rule by the emperor, and the sekkan were not appointed because Emperor Uda disgusted with the Ako Incident was not born from a mother from the Fujiwara family having an imperial mother, and because Tokihira, the head of the Fujiwara family, was still young.

sen.j: 897年（寛平9年）、宇多天皇は皇太子敦仁親王（醍醐天皇）に譲位し、その2年後に自ら造立した仁和寺で出家し法皇と称したが、病気がちの醍醐天皇に代わって、実際の政務を執っていたいう説もある。
sen.e: In 897, Emperor Uda abdicated the throne to Crown Prince Atsugimi (Emperor Daigo), and became a priest in Ninna-ji Temple built by himself and called himself Cloistered Emperor two years later, but there is an assumption that he actually managed political affairs in place of often-ailing Emperor Daigo.

sen.j: 「延喜天暦の治」と賞せられる醍醐天皇（延喜の治）・村上天皇（天暦の治）の「善政」とされるものの多くは寛平の治の政策の延長上に過ぎず、従来延喜年間のこととされている奴婢制度廃止令も寛平年中に出された形跡があるとする説がある。
sen.e: Most of what are called "good politics" in the eras of Emperor Daigo (Engi no chi) and Emperor Murakami (Tenryaku no chi) highly evaluated as "Engi-Tenryaku-no-chi" were only extensions of the political measures taken in Kanpyo no chi, and a theory tells there is an evidence that the abolition of slavery was issued in Kanpyo era, which is generally believed to have been issued in Enki era.

sen.j: 寛平の治は、王臣家が諸国富豪と直接結びつくことを規制することで権門（有力貴族・寺社）を抑制し、小農民を保護するという律令制への回帰を強く志向したものであり、併せて蔵人所の充実や検非違使庁の権限拡充等天皇直属機関の強化を行うものであった。
sen.e: Kanpyo no chi was strongly intended for a return to the Ritsuryo system that protected tenant farmers and suppressed influential families (noble families, temples and shrines with power) by restricting direct bondage between oshinke (nobles in the capital) and rich class in the provinces, and at the same time, also intended for a reinforcement of organizations ruled by the emperor, including an enhancement of the kurododokoro (the Chamberlain's Office) and an increase of authority of Kebiishicho (Office of Police and Judicial Chief).

sen.j: しかし、後の延喜の治とともに現実の社会制度の変革に適合せず必ずしも成功したとは言えなかった。
sen.e: However, like later Enki no chi, these measures did not fit the change of the real social system, and were hardly successful.
